bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Emma Coleman Carter, December 14, 1889

div1.p: Carter discusses his plans for next year. He does not know if he will stay, but wants his family in Virginia.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Emma Coleman Carter, December 14, 1889
div1.opener:
MARINE HOSPITAL SERVICE
1798 * U. S. * 1871
U. S. Marine-Hospital Service,
DISTRICT OF THE GULF,
Port of______________, Surgeon's Office,
_________, 18
Dec 14 /89
Dear Mother:
div1.p:
I suppose you got my
Tampa letter & I write this
so soon after because I fear that I will have
no other time befor Xmas; Ex-
actly what official work I will have
on hand when I get back, wil I
think will be Wednesday, (the 17
night. I am one day out from
Manatee now & will reach Mobile
tomorrow night (I fear for then I will
have considerable hotel bill). Have
one more tooth out & then for Biloxi
Dr. Vansant is in Mobile & I want
to stop & see him any way.

The more I think of Fla. the better
I like it; but I will wait until I can
sit down & think of it & form a sober
judgement of it. If nannie's boys were
a little older it would be possibly a
good thing for one (or two) of them
to try to have staid a place although
it isn't easy to find U. S. land
fit for any thing now. Unless the
grant of the S. F. R. R. be forfeited
still there is some. However there
will be opportunities there for 5 years
yet.

I am anxious to get back. Haven't any
14) 114 (9
idea that anyevery thing isn't right, but
haven't heard since& I left & left Laura
sick with a headache.

I can't say that I have greatly en-
joyed this trip, & made a mistake
in leaving one day too soon, but
taken all things together it was
fairly successful in finding out things &
enabling me to plan for the future as
well as to give directions for this next
year, & I hope that I need not go
next fall, although it is better I sh'd,
if practicable.

I do not know if I stay here another
summer or no: but rather expect it
If so I presume the work will be less
laborious & unpleasant than hitherto
- far less, & I won't have 1/20 of the
worry. I know well that I worry
too much anyway, but it isn't easy
to help it for one of my disposition.
It's foundation with me is (1) seeing
too clearly the other side of a question &
(2) Sensitiveness. That last quality
while doubtless it has its uses, is
no little in a man's way, & by no adds
to his comfort.

I want L & the children to go to Va.
& I presume Forest or Gale Hill would
do perfectly. Amherst is a more
beautiful country than Albe-
marle & I w'd like it better, but
Albemarle is more civilised & it
may be L. would prefer it. Either
will be better than Chandeleur.

Hope I can write again before Xmas
but, if I cannot, I will wish you all
now a happy Xmas & pleasant New Year
Dear Love to all at N River & in
Ashland. Where is Ned?
